node.title: Federal government champions gas-fired recovery, but regulator questions the cost to consumers
node.alt: Image of a gas ring burner on a stove
node.description: The energy regulator is concerned households that use gas could face significant future costs if the federal government continues to promote the gas sector while also aiming to reach net zero emissions by 2050.
node.content:
["The energy regulator is concerned households that use gas could face significant future costs if the federal government continues to promote the gas sector while also aiming to reach net zero emissions by 2050.\u00a0", "The recently adopted 2050 target \"appears contradictory\" to the federal government's national gas policy \"which encourages more gas consumption\", according to the Australian Energy Regulator (AER).", "The AER oversees the wholesale and retail energy markets, as well as electricity networks and natural gas pipelines.", "In a recently released paper, it examines the risk of the gas network continuing to expand in the short term, but having a shrinking customer base beyond the end of the decade as households and businesses replace gas with renewable alternatives. \u00a0", "That could see gas companies pass on the significant cost of servicing and maintaining pipelines to a smaller number of customers, driving up their bills.", "But AER Chair Clare Savage has told the ABC that \"it's not a time for consumers to panic\".", "\"Electricification will need to happen, but it's a long-term change,\" she said.", "\"It's just important we start thinking about these issues and we make minor adjustments as we go to make sure it's not a bumpy transition, but that it's smooth.\"", "
Transition away from gas 'inevitable'
", "The federal government considers the expansion of the gas sector crucial to economic growth and is opening up more gas basins for development and encouraging construction of more pipelines to reach both industry and households.", "The Coalition believes gas will maintain reliability in the electricity system as coal-fired power stations retire and renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power, become dominant.", "Around 4 million people currently use gas for heating and cooking in their homes but that will decline, according to Lynne Gallagher, CEO of independent advocacy group Energy Consumers Australia. \u00a0", "\"This transition is inevitable\u00a0so, in fact, adding more households\u00a0on to gas is only going to make the transition harder,\" she said.\u00a0", "", "
Clare Savage says there is no need for customers to panic.(ABC News: Amy Bainbridge)
", "Ms Gallagher wants to see more information and support for existing gas users to switch to electric options.", "\"There are costs for people in buying new appliances and they're often expensive,\" she said.\u00a0", "\"The other costs are for the people who are left still using gas. There is the possibility that those gas prices could go up and we need to manage those impacts.\"", "
Important to manage risk now
", "Gas pipelines generally have a life span of 50-80 years and the cost of construction is recovered over that time frame.", "Investment decisions being made now need to factor in the potential for very limited gas consumption, or none at all, in 30 years time.", "The ACT government has banned new gas connections to premises after 2023 and some households and businesses are voluntarily disconnecting gas services in favour of renewable energy sources.", "A recent report by the Grattan Institute suggests a widespread moratorium on new gas connections would ultimately help households save money.", "But the AER paper also notes demand for gas pipelines could remain strong if other technologies, such as carbon capture and storage, hydrogen or biomethane, become viable.", "A two-year trial of using gas blended with hydrogen began in Western Sydney on Thursday, an initiative supported by a multi-million dollar grant from the Australian Renewable Energy Agency", "\"Thinking about how we manage that risk now \u2014\u00a0noting that it is not clear yet whether demand [for gas pipelines]\u00a0goes up or down \u2014 could protect future customers and ensure ongoing, much needed investment in existing and new pipelines,\" Ms Savage said.", "The AER paper suggests accelerated depreciation of pipeline assets could reduce risks for gas companies, as well as considering alternatives fees and charges and different cost-sharing arrangements."]
